station.name: DEATHCORE/MELODIC DEATHCORE
station.longDesc: Deathcore - the direction of extreme metal, which is a merger of death metal with metalcore and / or hardcore. In deathcore riffs and blast beats from death metal and breakdowns from hardcore are often used. The speed and severity of the deathcore, as well as its chromatic muffled riffs and discord, have been influenced by modern death metal. Traditional growling and screaming are often used in the deathcore.

station.name: CRUST PUNK/NEOCRUST
station.longDesc: Crust punk is a musical direction that arose under the influence of hardcore punk, anarcho punk, extreme metal, which originated in the mid-80s in England. The songs are often filled with gloomy pessimistic lyrics about political and social issues.

station.name: HARDCORE PUNK
station.longDesc: Hardcore punk - a musical genre that appeared in the US and the UK in the late 1970s as a result of separation from punk rock. The sound, compared with the traditional sound of punk rock, has become faster, heavier, the songs have become shorter. In addition, the distinctive feature of hardcore punk is more blurry, syncopated riffs compared to punk rock.

station.name: RAPCORE
station.longDesc: Rapcore (or punk rap) is a genre of alternative rock music, characterized by using rap (recitative) as vocals. Rapcore combines the instrumental and vocal properties of areas such as punk rock, hardcore and hip hop.

station.name: METALCORE
station.longDesc: Metalcore is a subgenre of rock music, formed due to the mixing of various genres of metal and hardcore punk. Accordingly, from these genres, he received the name. The term in its current sense, appeared in the early 1990s, to describe the work of groups such as Earth Crisis, Deadguy and Integrity. The oldest of these groups appeared in 1988.

station.name: POST HARDCORE
station.longDesc: Posthardcore is a sub-genre of hardcore punk that emerged in the mid-to-late 1980s with the advent of releases in the Midwest USA. These include bands on SST Records, and bands from Washington, such as Fugazi (see, for example, releases from the Dischord Records era), as well as slightly different bands, such as Big Black and Jawbox, which are closer to noise-rock roots. post-hardcore.

station.name: GRINDCORE/DEATHGRIND
station.longDesc: Grindcore - an extreme direction of rock music, originally resulting from the mixture of crust-punk and thrash-playing. Also a role was played by the influence of metal. The name comes from the word English. grind - “grind” (because of the sound built on atonal riffs, “grinding”, “grinding”, passing from one to another).

station.name: MELODIC METALCORE
station.longDesc: In the early 2000s, a second wave of metalcore groups began to form. The distinguishing feature of these bands was a much stronger emphasis on the melodiousness of the music and a marked affinity with the post-hardcore groups.

station.name: MATHCORE/CHAOTIC HARDCORE
station.longDesc: Matkor - rhythmically complex and dissonant style of metalcore. It originates in the work of groups Converge, Botch and The Dillinger Escape Plan. The term matkor is used by analogy with the mat-rock. Both matkor and mat-rock use non-standard beat sizes. Mat-rock bands such as Slint, Don Caballero, Shellac and Drive Like Jehu had some influence on the core, even though he was more close to the metalcore.

station.name: HARDCORE/MELODIC HARDCORE
station.longDesc: Hardcore is a heavy and tougher punk rock that appeared in the United States and was first sounded in 1977 on the Black Flag debut demo. Besides them, the first hardcore bands were Circle Jerks, Teen Idles, Minor Threat, Jerry's Kids, Bad Brains. The very first hardcore longplay Group Sex was released in 1980 by the band Circle Jerks, founded by the first vocalist of Black Flag, however, mass recognition came to the genre after the release of the album Black Flag Damaged.

station.name: EMOCORE/SCREAMO/EMO VIOLENCE
station.longDesc: Emo is a style of rock music characterized by melodic musicality and expressive lyrics. He appeared in the mid-1980s in Washington, where he was known as 'emotional hardcore punk' or 'Emokor', developed by groups such as Rites of Spring and Embrace. The style was reworked by American punk rockers, its sound changed, mixed with pop punk and indie rock and recorded in the early 1990s by Jawbreaker and Sunny Day Real Estate.

station.name: ELECTRONICORE/TRANCECORE
station.longDesc: Elektronikor is a music genre that mixes elements of modern metalcore and / or post-hardcore with electronic music. He gained maximum popularity among metalcore groups in the 2000s with echoes of manifestations in England, USA, Canada, France and Hong Kong.

station.name: PROGRESSIVE METALCORE
station.longDesc: Progressive Metalcore - metal music style. Appeared in the mid-1990s with the work of groups such as Converge, Botch and The Dillinger Escape Plan. The term itself was coined by analogy with progressive rock. Combines such styles as progressive metal and metalcore. Progressive metalcore is characterized by high speed (often abrupt cliffs of a musical phrase), 'slip', technical performance and an unusual rhythm in combination with many progressive elements.

station.name: BEATDOWN/MOSHCORE/DOWNTEMPO HARDCORE/METALCORE
station.longDesc: Bitdown hardcore is closely related to hip-hop, the music is characterized by a large number of breakdowns. This trend in music began almost with the birth of hardcore. Often sounding with a big Mosh / Moshcore mix.
